Fig. 1 Rates of ammonia synthesis achieved using the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts at 0.1 MPa. Catalyst = 0.2 g, a feed gas H2/N2 ratio of 3.0, flow rate = 80 mL min−1. (a) Effect of temperature on the catalytic process. The dashed line denotes the equilibrium rate. (b) Effect of the Si content on the rate of ammonia synthesis at 350 °C. Error bars represent standard deviations from three replicate measurements for Ru/CLS10. Data for other catalysts are based on single measurements. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Rates of ammonia synthesis achieved over the Ru/CLS0, Ru/CLS10, and Cs/Ru/MgO catalysts: (a) at a feed gas H2/N2 ratio of 3.0 as a function of pressure, and (b) at a pressure of 5.1 MPa as a function of the feed gas H2/N2 ratio. Reaction conditions: catalyst volume = 1 mL, flow rate = 400 mL min−1, temperature = 320 °C. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the Ru/CLSX (X = 0–50), Ru/CeO2, and Ru/SiO2 catalysts, all reduced at 600 °C. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Pore size distribution curves for the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts, all reduced at 600 °C. (b) Pore volumes associated with the 2–10 and 10–50 nm pores as a function of the Si content. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM images of the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10, and 30) and Ru/SiO2 catalysts. (a) Ru/CLS0, (b) Ru/CLS10, (c) Ru/CLS30, (d) Ru/SiO2, and (e) Ru/CLS10 reduced at 600 °C. The bright particles shown in panels (b) and (c) are CeO2-La2O3-SiO2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) FTIR spectra of the CLSX and SiO2 supports, and (b) FTIR spectra of the CLS10 support, a physical mixture of the CLS0 and SiO2 supports with the same composition as the CLS10 support, and the Ru/CLS10 catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 ADF-STEM and elemental mapping images for the catalysts reduced at 600 °C: (a) Ru/CLS0, (b) Ru/CLS10, (c) Ru/CLS30, and (d) Ru/SiO2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Relationship between the SSAs and the pore volume of 2–10 nm for the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts. (b) Relationship between the Ru dispersions and the pore volume of 10–50 nm for the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Shifts in the absorption edge energies of the Ru/CLSX catalysts upon increasing the temperature from 50 to 600 °C under a 5 % H2/He gas flow. The results for the (a) Ce-K edge, (b) Ru-K edge, and (c) Ce-K and Ru-K edges are shown (Ru/CLS10 catalyst only for panel (c)). The circles (●) indicate the edge energies before H2/He treatment at 50 °C, while the squares (■) indicate the edge energies after reduction at 600 °C for 30 min. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 TOFs of the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts at 350 °C and 0.1 MPa. The TOF was calculated from the number of active sites obtained by CO chemisorption experiments and the rate of ammonia synthesis at 350 °C and 0.1 MPa. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Images of the support morphologies and Ru distributions corresponding to the catalytic activities of the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts. Toyota Central R&D Labs., Inc Nagakute Aichi 480-1192 Japan 1 orcid.org/0000-0002-9220-1883 Green ammonia has attracted growing attention as an energy carrier to facilitate the storage and transport of hydrogen that is derived from renewable energy sources. It is therefore necessary to develop catalysts that can efficiently synthesize ammonia under milder conditions (<10 MPa) than those required by conventional catalysts (15–30 MPa). In this study, Si is doped into Ru/CeO2-La2O3 catalysts prepared via a polymerization complexation method to promote the synthesis of ammonia over the generated mesoporous structure. Scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffractometry, N2 adsorption, attenuated total reflection–Fourier transform infrared spectrometry, and CO adsorption measurements revealed that for the CeO2-La2O3 support, Si doping at levels of ≤ 10 mol% created a mesoporous structure (10–50 nm range) through aggregation of the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution with a smaller particle size than that of undoped particles. Consequently, this resulted in an enhanced Ru dispersion and an improved catalytic activity. However, Si doping at levels > 10 mol% led to the formation of isolated SiO2 particles bearing inactive Ru species, thereby resulting in a lower catalytic activity. Notably, compared to the catalyst without Si doping, the 10 mol% Si-doped Ru/CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 catalyst exhibited a 3.5-fold higher rate for ammonia synthesis at a reaction pressure of 5.1 MPa. This system is therefore expected to promote ammonia synthesis under mild conditions, ultimately contributing to the transition from a fossil fuel-based society to a hydrogen-based society. Graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia synthesis Ru catalyst Cerium–lanthanum composite oxide Si-doping Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels are the dominant energy sources used to power modern life; however, they emit significant amounts of CO2, which promotes global warming. Consequently, various governments have proposed a variety of solutions to achieve "carbon neutrality," i.e., reaching net-zero CO2 emissions, by ∼2050. As a potential solution to this challenge, ammonia is attracting growing attention because it is an excellent "carrier" for hydrogen, and has the potential to replace fossil fuels. Although hydrogen derived from renewable energy sources is a clean and environmentally friendly fuel, its storage requires significant energy inputs to perform cryogenic cooling (i.e., to −253 °C) or high-pressure compression (20–69 MPa) [1]. In contrast, ammonia is easily liquefied at 0.9 MPa at 25 °C, and its volumetric hydrogen density is > 1.5 times that of liquid hydrogen [2]. Ammonia can be efficiently converted to hydrogen via decomposition, and the direct combustion of ammonia or its co-firing with conventional fossil fuels can ultimately reduce CO2 emissions [3,4]. The Haber–Bosch (HB) process, which is the most commonly applied protocol for ammonia synthesis using iron catalysts is currently based on the consumption of fossil fuels, resulting in ∼1.6 tons of CO2 emissions per ton of ammonia produced [5]. It is therefore necessary to replace the energy sources used in this process with renewable alternatives. In addition, the HB process consumes enormous amounts of energy for ammonia production due to its requirement for high temperatures (400–500 °C) and pressures (15–30 MPa) [6]. Consequently, the development of advanced catalysts that can operate under mild conditions is necessary to reduce energy consumption [7,8]. In this context, Ru catalysts are well known to exhibit high activities under mild conditions, and have been investigated as alternatives to iron catalysts for the synthesis of ammonia [6,9,10]. For the typical Ru/MgO catalysts, it has been reported that their activities can be promoted by the addition of alkali metals [9,10]. Carbon-supported Ru (Ru/C) catalysts also demonstrate high activities, and have been commercialized for use in the KBR Advanced Ammonia Process (KAAP) [11]. However, further development is required for their widespread practical application because the simultaneous production of methane leads to a poor catalyst durability. Aika et al. found that Ru catalysts supported on lanthanide oxides, such as Ru/CeO2, Ru/Sm2O3, and Ru/La2O3, are effective for ammonia synthesis, with Ru/CeO₂ in particular maintaining stable activity over extended periods [12,13]. Since then, numerous researchers have investigated Ru catalysts supported on lanthanide oxides for ammonia synthesis [14–19]. Indeed, our group previously demonstrated that a Ru/CeO2 catalyst exhibits a good long-term durability in a 20 kg d−1 ammonia synthesis system with an incorporated recycling loop [17]. It has been reported that the dissociative adsorption of N2 on the catalyst active sites represents the rate-determining step in the synthesis of ammonia, and electron donation to the active sites has been shown to be effective in accelerating this step [10,20–22]. In the case of Ru/CeO2 catalyst systems, the activity is enhanced by electron donation to Ru from Ce3+, which is generated by the reduction pre-treatment of CeO2 at high temperatures [12,13]. In addition, the structure and dispersion of the Ru active sites on the CeO2 support contribute to the overall catalytic activity [18,19,23,24]. For Ru nanoparticles, a particle size of approximately 2 nm is considered optimal for maximizing the number of B5-type sites that promote the dissociative adsorption of N2 [24,25]. In contrast, extensive theoretical and experimental investigations have been conducted on Ru clusters smaller than 2 nm, revealing not only the activation of N2 through dissociative adsorption but also the possibility of alternative associative reaction mechanisms [26–28]. Previously, our group found a relationship between the morphology and structure of the CeO2 support and the dispersion of Ru, and proposed design guidelines for the preparation of Ru/CeO2-based catalysts [24]. Among composite oxides containing CeO2, CeO2–La2O3 has been extensively studied as a support for Ru catalysts in ammonia synthesis [29–33]. Ru/ CeO2–La2O3 catalysts have demonstrated enhanced and stable ammonia synthesis activity, attributed to La doping, which facilitates the reduction of surface oxygen in cerium oxide and promotes electron donation from Ce³ ⁺ to Ru [29]. Furthermore, this doping effect has been reported to be intensified by high-temperature pre-reduction at 650 °C [30]. Additionally, our group discovered that doping the Ru/CeO2–La2O3 catalyst with Ti further improves catalytic activity through the formation of a mesoporous structure [34]. As a further development, doping Ru/CeO2-La2O3 catalysts with Si, which possesses a smaller ionic radius than Ti, is expected to have a greater effect on the structural changes of the support and the resulting dispersion of Ru. Indeed, it has been reported that the combination of a Ru/CeO2 catalyst with SiO2 enhances the catalytic activity by tuning the adsorption and desorption properties of hydrogen species [35]. However, the pore structure of the catalyst and the reducibility of the support were not fully discussed. Thus, in the current study, CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 composite oxides are synthesized using a complex polymerization method, and the effects of Si doping on the structure of the support and the dispersion of Ru are thoroughly investigated. Subsequently, the catalytic activity is investigated using an appropriately adjusted H2/N2 ratio, and the effect of Si doping on the interactions between the Ru active sites and the CeO2 support in the Ru/CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 system is investigated to elucidate the mechanism responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity. 2 Methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ce0.5La0.5−ySiyO1.75+0.5y (y = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5) composite oxides were prepared using the polymerization complexation approach [34]. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (98 %, Tokyo Chemical Industry) and ethylene glycol (99 %, FUJIFILM Wako) were mixed at a volume ratio of 1:1 to obtain a two-phase liquid [36]. A transparent Si solution was obtained by adding trace nitric acid (65 %, FUJIFILM Wako) to the two-phase liquid, followed by stirring at 80 °C. Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (98 %, FUJIFILM Wako), La(NO3)3·6 H2O (99.9 %, FUJIFILM Wako), the Si solution, ethylene glycol, and citric acid (98 %, FUJIFILM Wako) were dissolved in deionized water in a molar ratio of 0.5:(0.5 −y):y:12:6. The resulting mixed solution, containing the Ce, La, and Si components was stirred at 90 °C for 1 h to induce polymerization, then dried at 300 °C until gelatinization was achieved. Subsequently, the obtained gel was heated at 500 °C for 5 h and calcined twice at 700 °C for 10 h under air. The obtained support was denoted as CLSX, where X is the Si content (%) of the total cation composition (Ce+La+Si) (e.g., the support containing 10 mol% Si (y = 0.1) was denoted as CLS10). Similarly, the SiO2 support was synthesized using only the aqueous Si solution, without the incorporation of Ce or La nitrates. The corresponding Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50) and Ru/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation using a solution of Ru3(CO)12 (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99.5 %, FUJIFILM Wako). The samples were dried overnight at 80 °C and then calcined at 300 °C for 1 h under 4 % H2/N2 gas. After calcination, the catalysts were exposed to the atmosphere and stored overnight. The loading of metallic Ru loading was 3 wt% on a nominal basis for each catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis of the supports was performed using a ZSX Primus II instrument (Rigaku). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were obtained on a Rigaku Ultima IV instrument at 40 kV and 40 mA using Cu Kα radiation. The specific surface areas (SSAs) of the catalysts were determined according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) one-point method using a Microdata Microsorp 4232II instrument. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained from backscattered electron images using a Regulus8230 (Hitachi High-Tech). The attenuated total reflection–Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra of the samples were recorded using a diamond ATR accessory and a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured at –196 °C using a BELSORP-mini II instrument (MicrotracBEL) after pretreatment at 300 °C for 30 min under vacuum (10−5 Torr). The pore volume was calculated from the isotherms obtained using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (ADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were performed using a JEM-2100F instrument (JEOL) at 200 kV. The CO chemisorption properties of the catalysts were measured using an R6015-S instrument (Hemmi Slide Rule Co.) [37]. For this purpose, the catalysts were reduced at 600 °C for 30 min in a H2 environment, and then cooled to the measurement temperature (−78 °C) under a flow of He. The amount of adsorbed CO was determined using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Ru particle size was calculated by assuming a 1:1 ratio of surface metal atoms to the adsorbed CO molecules. Operando X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements were performed at the Toyota Beamline (BL33XU) of the SPring-8 facility [38]. The Ru and Ce K-edge XAFS spectra were measured in the transmission mode using ionization chambers. The incident X-rays were monochromatized using a channel-cut Si (111) monochromator for the Ru measurements, and using Si (220) for the Ce measurements. The analytical samples were prepared by physical mixing of the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10, and 30) catalysts with γ-Al2O3 (Nikki-Universal, TN-4) in a weight ratio of 8:2. Subsequently, the mixture was pressed into a disk (10 mm diameter) and loaded into the cell for measurement. A 5 % H2/He gas mixture was then introduced into the cell at a total gas flow rate of 150 mL min−1. The reduction temperature was then increased from 50 to 600 °C at a rate of 20 °C min−1. This procedure corresponds to a H₂ temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR) measurement. The Ru and Ce K-edge XAFS spectra were collected at 5 °C intervals during the reduction process and after 30 min of holding at 600 °C. The valence changes were estimated from the absorption edge energy shift using an empirical approach [19,39,40], wherein the absorption edge energy is defined as the photon energy with a normalized XANES value of 0.5 (Figure S1). 2.3 Evaluation of the catalytic activity for the synthesis of ammonia The activities of the prepared catalysts in the synthesis of ammonia were evaluated under ambient (0.1 MPa) and high (0.1–5.1 MPa) pressure conditions in a fixed-bed reactor. High-purity gases (99.99995 % N2, 99.99999 % H2, Taiyo Nippon Sanso JFP) were used to perform the reduction pre-treatment and catalytic activity tests. For the measurements performed at ambient pressure, the fresh catalyst (0.2 g) was loaded into a quartz tube and reduced at 600 °C for 30 min under a mixed gas flow with a H2/N2 ratio of 3.0 at 80 mL min−1. The concentration of ammonia in the outlet gas was measured using FTIR spectroscopy. For measurement of the rate of synthesis, the error was determined to be approximately ±0.05 mmol g−1 h−1. Figure S2 shows a schematic diagram of the fixed-bed reactor system used for high-pressure ammonia synthesis. To evaluate the catalytic activity under high pressure conditions, the fresh catalyst (1.0 mL) was packed into a stainless tube and reduced at 600 °C for 1 h at ambient pressure under a mixed gas flow with a H2/N2 ratio of 3.0 at 400 mL min−1, then exposed to the desired temperature and pressure conditions. As above, the concentration of ammonia in the outlet gas was measured using FTIR spectroscopy. The rate of ammonia synthesis was determined from the average ammonia concentration over a period of 5 min after stabilization. The reaction order for this process was determined by kinetic analysis according to the method described by Aika et al. [41]. All data were collected at 320 °C and 0.1 MPa. The reaction conditions are listed in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of ammonia using the Si-doped Ru/CLSX catalysts The rates of ammonia synthesis achieved over the Ru/CLSX (X = 0–50 %) and Ru/SiO2 catalysts under ambient pressure (at 0.1 MPa) are illustrated in Fig. 1(a). As indicated, the activity improved upon the addition of 10 mol% Si, with a particularly high catalytic activity being observed for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst. Indeed, the rate achieved using the Ru/CLS10 catalyst (i.e., 3.85 mmol g−1 h−1) was ∼1.8-times higher than that achieved using the Ru/CLS0 catalyst (i.e., 2.14 mmol g−1 h−1) at 350 °C, where the equilibrium concentration is sufficiently high. However, upon further increasing the Si content, the activity tended to decrease, and the Ru/SiO2 catalyst showed almost no activity below 400 °C (Fig. 1(b)). Subsequently, the reaction order of the most active catalyst (i.e., Ru/CLS10) was analyzed and compared with those of the base catalyst (Ru/CLS0) and the reference catalyst (Cs/Ru/MgO), based on our previous work ( Table 1, Figure S3) [34]. From the table, it is evident that the reaction order of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst was relatively close to that of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, but showed a different tendency from that of the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst, suggesting that Si doping of the Ru/Ce0.5La0.5O1.75 catalyst did not alter its reaction properties. The reaction order of NH3 (ammonia) for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst is close to zero (−0.29), thereby indicating that the influence of the ammonia generated by the reaction was weak. Therefore, the Ru/CLS10 catalyst was expected to exhibit a high activity under high-pressure conditions to promote ammonia production. The reaction order of H2 for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst was almost zero (−0.07), representing a larger than that obtained for the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst (−0.45), and indicating that the effect of hydrogen poisoning was suppressed more effectively compared to the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst. Conversely, the N2 reaction order was larger for the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst (1.50) than for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst (0.70), indicating that the activity increased rapidly with an increasing N2 partial pressure due to strong hydrogen poisoning in the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst. Indeed, hydrogen poisoning of the Ru surface is a major challenge for the application of Ru catalysts in the ammonia synthesis reaction [42]. Recently, the phenomenon of hydrogen spillover has been reported to help mitigate hydrogen poisoning [23,43–46]. To date, the effects of hydrogen spillover on electride and oxyhydride supports have been actively investigated [22,43,45]. Furthermore, hydrogen spillover has also been observed on reducible metal oxides such as CeO2 and WO3, where hydrogen atoms reduce the metal oxides and diffuse across their surfaces [47–49]. This phenomenon is believed to alleviate hydrogen poisoning at active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. The suppression of hydrogen poisoning in the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10) catalysts was therefore attributed to the reducible CLSX support. Tsang et al. recently reported that hydrogen poisoning can be alleviated by promoting hydrogen spillover in Cs/Ru/MgO(111) catalysts when using an electrostatically polar MgO support. However, this effect was found to be weak when nonpolar or commercially available MgO supports were employed [50]. Therefore, the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst used in this study is considered to have exhibited significant hydrogen poisoning, as hydrogen spillover was energetically unfavorable due to the use of a non-reductive and nonpolar MgO support. 3.2 Activity of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst in the synthesis of ammonia under high pressure conditions Subsequently, the activities of the Ru/CLS10, Ru/CLS0, and Cs/Ru/MgO catalysts were evaluated under high pressure conditions ( Fig. 2). As a result, it was found that the Ru/CLS10 catalyst exhibited the highest activity at pressures up to 5.1 MPa. Additionally, the activities of the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10) catalysts increased at higher reaction pressures, whereas that of the Cs/Ru/MgO catalyst remained virtually unchanged. According to the equilibrium of the ammonia synthesis reaction, a higher pressure favors a higher activity. The increased activity of the Ru/CLSX catalyst was therefore attributed to reduced inhibition by hydrogen poisoning, which is consistent with the reaction order analysis. Furthermore, the effect of the reaction gas composition (i.e., the H2/N2 ratio) was investigated at the optimal pressure of 5.1 MPa (Fig. 2(b)). Independent of the gas composition, it was found that the Ru/CLS10 catalyst demonstrated a higher activity than the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, with the former exhibiting a 3.5-fold higher rate of ammonia synthesis (21.7 mmol g−1 h−1) than the latter (6.1 mmol g−1 h−1) at a H2/N2 ratio of 0.5. Upon reducing the H2/N2 ratio, the activities of both the catalysts tended to increase. More specifically, using the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, a 2.7-fold higher reaction rate was achieved with a H2/N2 ratio of 0.5, compared to that obtained using a H2/N2 ratio of 3.0. Although the theoretical stoichiometric ratio of H2/N2 for ammonia synthesis is 3.0, a low H2/N2 ratio mitigates H2 poisoning and increases the rate of ammonia synthesis. Figure S4 shows the time-dependent relative ammonia synthesis activity of Ru/CLS10. The activity gradually decreased overtime and declined to approximately 80 % of the initial value after around 140 h. Such a decrease in activity has also been reported for Ru/CeO₂-based catalysts, and it is presumed to be caused by the reoxidation of Ce3+ due to trace impurities (H₂O, O₂, CO₂) present in the feed gas [19,30]. However, the catalytic activity was restored to its initial level after H₂ reduction treatment at 600 °C, indicating that the deactivation was reversible. 3.3 Characterization of the Ru/CLSX catalysts Table S2 presents the cationic ratios of the supports as determined by XRF analysis. Although all supports exhibited a slightly lower silicon content compared to the nominal values, the results indicate that the target compositions were generally well achieved. The Ru/CLSX, Ru/CeO2, and Ru/SiO2 catalysts, all reduced at 600 °C, were characterized by XRD, as detailed in Fig. 3. Fluorite-type patterns were obtained for the Ru/CLSX catalysts, with no peaks attributed to SiO2 being observed. In the case of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, the peaks were observed at lower angles than those of the Ru/CeO2 catalyst, which was attributed to the La3+ ions present in the solid solution possessing a larger ionic radius than the Ce4+ ions, which resulted in a larger lattice constant. The absence of La2O3 diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns is attributed to the formation of a solid solution in which La3+ ions are homogeneously incorporated into the fluorite structure of CeO2. For the Ru/CLSX catalysts, the peaks were found to shift to higher angles as the Si content was increased ( Table 2), likely due to the replacement of La3+ with Si4+, which possesses a smaller ionic radius and leads to a reduced lattice constant. Furthermore, a peak shift to higher angles was observed for the Ce0.5La0.4Si0.1O1.8 support and the Ru/CLS10 catalyst compared with that of the Ce0.5La0.4O1.6 support with the same Ce/La composition ratio (Figure S5). These results suggest that at least a portion of the doped Si4+, which has a smaller ionic radius than the Ce4+ and La3+ ions, was incorporated within the Ce0.5La0.4O1.6 crystal structure to form a solid solution. Consequently, Si doping appeared to reduce the crystallite size of the fluorite structure in the Ru/CLSX catalyst, as estimated from the XRD patterns (Table 2). In particular, the fact that the crystallite sizes of the Ru/CLSX (5 ≤ X ≤ 40) catalysts are smaller than those of the Ru/CLS0 and Ru/CLS50 catalysts indicates that the mixture of the three oxides (i.e., CeO2-La2O3-SiO2) is more effective in inhibiting particle aggregation (CLS0 = CeO2-La2O3; CLS50 = CeO2-SiO2). The SSAs of the Ru/CLSX and Ru/SiO2 catalysts are listed in Table 2, wherein it can be seen that the SSA of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst reaches an extremely low value of 10 m2 g−1. Upon increasing the Si content, the SSAs of the Ru/CLSX catalysts increased, while the Ru/SiO2 catalyst exhibited an extremely large SSA of 550 m2 g−1. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the Ru/CLSX catalysts with different Si contents and the Ru/SiO2 catalyst, all of which were reduced at 600 °C, are shown in Figure S6, while the pore distribution curves are presented in Fig. 4(a). In the case of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst, a distinct hysteresis loop indicating the formation of mesopores was observed (Figure S6), and the pore distribution curve revealed numerous 2–10 nm pores attributed to the fine or amorphous SiO2 particles (Fig. 4(a)). In contrast, the Ru/CLS0 catalyst (i.e., without Si doping) contained few 2–10 nm pores, and the pore volume associated with pores measuring > 10 nm was small. For the Ru/CLSX catalysts with X ≥ 20, the pore volume associated with the 2–10 nm pores tended to increase with an increasing Si content, which can be attributed to the pores of the SiO2 component. In contrast, compared to the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, the Ru/CLS5 and Ru/CLS10 catalysts exhibited lower pore volumes attributed to 2–10 nm pores, suggesting that SiO2 formation was less pronounced in these species. The mesopores (2–50 nm) present in the Ru/CLSX catalysts can be classified into two types, namely small pores (2–10 nm) derived from the SiO2 particles and large pores (10–50 nm). The relationship between the volumes of these two pore types and the Si content was therefore analyzed, and the results are presented in Fig. 4(b) and Table 2. For Ru/CLSX catalysts with X ≥ 20, the pore volume associated with the 2–10 nm pores increased with an increasing Si content. In contrast, for the Ru/CLS5 and Ru/CLS10 catalysts, this pore volume decreased, while that associated with the 10–50 nm pores increased. Since the pore volumes associated with the 10–50 nm pores were extremely low for the Ru/SiO2 and Ru/CLS0 catalysts, these larger (10–50 nm) pores were assumed originate from the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 support. Consequently, the increased SSAs observed for the Ru/CLS5 and Ru/CLS10 catalysts were attributed to the increased SSAs of their CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 supports, while those observed for the Ru/SCSX catalysts with X ≥ 20 were primarily due to SiO2 formation. The SEM images recorded for the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10, and 30) and Ru/SiO2 catalysts, are shown in Figs. 5(a)–5(d). In the case of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, Ce0.5La0.5O1.75 particles of several hundred nanometers in size can be observed, which aggregate to form larger particles. In contrast, the Ru/CLS10 catalyst exhibits a porous structure bearing 20–100 nm pores, and its support morphology is significantly different from that of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst. In the elemental mapping images obtained for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, no SiO2 aggregation was observed, and the majority of the support was expected to be a solid solution of CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 (Figure S7). Analysis of the Ru/CLS30 catalyst revealed that these CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles (bright particles) were distributed on the aggregated SiO2 particles (dark particles). As the Si content was increased, the amount of Si began to exceed the solid solution limit of the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 system, and the excess Si was considered to aggregate as SiO2 particles. Although the porous structure was not as clear as that of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles in the Ru/CLS30 catalyst were found to be finer (several tens of nanometers) than those in the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, suggesting that Si was present in the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 support of the Ru/CLS30 catalyst, similar to the case of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst. Additionally, the SiO2 particles (dark particles) in the Ru/CLS30 catalyst exhibited rough surfaces, similar to those in the Ru/SiO2 catalyst. It was therefore considered that the higher SSA achieved upon increasing the Si content in the Ru/CLSX catalysts was due to the formation of SiO2 particles with higher SSAs. Furthermore, the formation of porous structures within the Ru/CLSX catalysts was attributed to the polymerization complexation method employed during their synthesis. More specifically, the porous structure is believed to form when the organic molecules (citric acid and ethylene glycol) added during preparation of the support decompose during calcination and are released as gases such as CO2. Although the majority of these pores collapsed in the case of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, it was assumed that Si doping prevented sintering of the support particles, and ultimately preserved the mesoporous structure of the support in the Ru/CLS10 catalyst. The mesoporous structure was also observed in the Ru/CLS10 catalyst after reduction at 600 °C, confirming that this structure was retained even after the reduction treatment (Fig. 5(e)). Fig. 6 shows the FTIR spectra recorded for the CLSX and SiO2 supports. In the spectrum corresponding to the SiO2 support, the peaks at 800 cm−1 (symmetric stretching vibrations) and 1060 cm−1 (asymmetric stretching vibrations) were attributed to the Si–O–Si bonds [51,52]. In contrast, no such peaks were observed for the CLS0 support, thereby suggesting that these peaks provide evidence of SiO2 formation. Indeed, compared to the CLS0 support, the intensity of the 1060 cm−1 increased upon increasing the degree of Si doping for all CLSX supports (X ≥ 5), thereby suggesting that SiO2 was formed in the CLSX supports (X ≥ 5). However, significantly lower peak intensities were observed at 1060 cm−1 for the CLS5 and CLS10 compared to those of the other CLSX supports, indicating that very little SiO2 was formed in these cases. Additionally, a new peak was also observed at 900 cm−1 for the CLSX supports (X ≥ 5), which was attributed to the Si–O–Ce bonds (X ≥ 5) [51,52]. Compared with a physical mixture of CLS0 and SiO2 containing the same amount of Si, the 900 cm−1 peak was more intense for the CLS10 support, while the peak intensity at 1060 cm−1 was significantly lower (Fig. 6(b)). These results imply that the majority of doped Si in this support is dissolved in the CeO2-La2O3 particles. Moreover, the spectrum recorded for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst calcined at 600 °C in a reducing atmosphere was similar to that of the CLS10 support (Fig. 6(b)), indicating that the Si–O–Ce state in the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution was maintained without SiO2 formation after the reductive treatment. 3.4 Dispersion of the Ru active sites The ADF-STEM and elemental mapping images of the Ru/CLSX (X = 0, 10, and 30) and Ru/SiO2 catalysts, all reduced at 600 °C, are shown in Fig. 7. It can be seen that the elemental distributions of Ce and La are similar in the Ru/CLSX catalysts, thereby indicating that the Ce mappings are representative. The STEM image of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst reveals Ru particles measuring ∼2–8 nm in size, while in the STEM image of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, Ru particles measuring ∼2–3 nm are present. For the Ru/CLS30 catalyst, the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles were selected for observation instead of the SiO2 particles for comparison with the Ru particles supported on the CLS10. The Ru particles attached to the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles were found to measure ∼2–3 nm in size, similar to those on the Ru/CLS10 catalyst. Elemental mapping of the Ru/CLS10 and Ru/CLS30 catalysts demonstrated that Si was not aggregated, and was instead homogeneously distributed within the particles of the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 support. Additionally, the STEM image of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst also reveals highly dispersed Ru particles measuring 2–3 nm in size. This observation suggests that the low activity of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst is not due to a low dispersion of Ru. Considering that electron donation from the CeO2 support to Ru has been reported to contribute to the high activities exhibited by Ru/CeO2 catalysts [12,30], the low activity of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst was likely due to the reduced degree of electron donation from the SiO2 support to the Ru particles. Subsequently, the average Ru particle size and dispersion was estimated for each of the Ru/CLSX catalysts using the CO chemisorption approach (Table 2). It was found that the average Ru particle size for the Ru/CLS0 catalyst (i.e., without Si) was ∼5.5 nm, consistent with the STEM observations (Fig. 7). In contrast, the Ru/CLSX (X ≥ 5) catalyst exhibited a smaller average Ru particle size of 2–3 nm, indicating the presence of highly dispersed Ru particles. The high dispersions of Ru in the Ru/CLSX (X ≥ 5) catalysts can be attributed to refinement of the support upon Si doping, namely an increased SSA and a larger pore volume. The relationships between the pore volume, SSA, and Ru dispersion are shown in Figures 8 and S8. More specifically, the SSA showed a strong correlation with a pore volume of 2–10 nm ( Fig. 8(a)), but a low correlation with a pore volume of 10–50 nm (Figure S8(a)). The Ru dispersion showed no correlation with a pore volume of 2–10 nm (Figure S8(b)), but exhibited a modest correlation with a pore volume of 10–50 nm (Fig. 8(b)). These results indicate that a pore volume of 2–10 nm, which correlates with the SSA, contributes little to the dispersion of Ru. The pore volume of 2–10 nm was mainly derived from the SiO2 particles, while the pore volume of 10–50 nm was primarily attributed to the pores of the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles. Therefore, an increase in the mesoporous structure derived from the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 particles may have contributed to the improved Ru dispersion. In contrast, the Ru dispersion of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst remained comparable to or poorer than those of the Ru/CLSX (X ≥ 5) catalysts, despite its extremely high SSA. 3.5 Operando XAFS analysis The valence changes of Ru and Ce in the Ru/CLSX catalysts under reductive conditions were subsequently investigated using the operando XAFS technique to understand the reducibility of the Ru sites and the CLSX supports, as well as the interactions between them. In general, a higher absorption edge energy (see 2.2) indicates a higher valence, as indicated in Figure S1. Thus, the valence change of Ru in the catalyst was estimated using the absorption edge energies of RuO2 and Ru metal as Ru4+ and Ru0 standards, while the valence change of Ce in the catalyst was estimated using the absorption edge energies of CeO2 and Ce2(CO3)3·8 H2O as Ce4+ and Ce3+ standards [19,40]. Fig. 9 shows the changes in the absorption edge energies of the Ru/CLS0, Ru/CLS10, and Ru/CLS30 catalysts upon increasing the temperature from 50 to 600 °C under reductive conditions. The valence changes in Ce revealed that the amount of Ce that was reduced from Ce4+ to Ce3+ increased with an increasing Si content (Fig. 9(a)). The reduction of Ce was further promoted by holding at 600 °C for 30 min under reductive conditions (■ in Fig. 9(a)), and the ratio of Ce3+ increased to 31 % for the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, 51 % for the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, and 75 % for the Ru/CLS30 catalyst. These results indicate that the reduction of Ce was enhanced by the addition of Si. Additionally, the percentages of reducible Ce present on the particle surfaces, as calculated from the SSAs and using 2.15 mol O2 m−2 as the amount of reduced oxygen per surface area, were determined to be ∼3, 9, and 29 %, respectively [53]. Therefore, the percentage of Ce on the particle surfaces of the CLSX supports was lower than the percentage of reduced Ce3+ determined from the XAFS measurements. The Ce present on the particle surfaces of the CLSX supports would be more easily reduced than the Ce present inside the particles. Therefore, it is presumed that after pretreatment at 600 °C for 30 min, almost all surface Ce in the CLSX supports are reduced, and only Ce3+, and not Ce4+, is in contact with the Ru sites. The Ru present in the catalysts was expected to be in an oxidized state prior to performing the XAFS evaluations since the Ru catalysts were reduced during catalyst preparation and prior to storage under atmospheric conditions. However, for the Ru/CLS0 catalyst, a large ratio of Ru metal was identified even before reduction process (● in Fig. 9(b)). The Ru particle size of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst (5.5 nm) was larger than those of the Ru/CLS10 and Ru/CLS30 catalysts (2–3 nm; Table 2), thereby implying that the central core of the Ru particles was not oxidized after exposure to the atmosphere, and remained in a metallic state. Additionally, after reduction at 600 °C, the Ru species present in all catalysts was reduced to Ru metal, regardless of the Si content (Fig. 9(b)). Comparing the shifts in the edge energies of Ru and Ce on the Ru/CLS10 catalyst (Fig. 9(c)), it was evident that a large amount of Ce4+ was also reduced at 100–200 °C, at which point the majority of Ru was also reduced. This finding indicates that either the reduction of Ru promotes the reduction of Ce, or the reduction of Ce promotes the reduction of Ru through interactions between Ru and CeOx in the support. It was also found that the Ru components of the Ru/CLSX catalysts were more easily reduced in the presence of lower Si contents (Fig. 9(b)), thereby suggesting that the interactions between Ru and CeOx were stronger with lower Si contents in the Ru/CLSX catalysts. 3.6 Evaluation of the catalytic activity The turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the Ru/CLXS and Ru/SiO2 catalysts were determined, and the obtained results are shown in Fig. 10. As indicated, the TOF decreased upon increasing the Si content, and the TOF of the Ru/SiO2 catalyst was found to be two orders of magnitude lower than that of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst. Previously, it has been reported that Ru particles measuring ∼2 nm exhibit the maximum number of active sites for ammonia synthesis, which are known as B5-type sites, and consequently, they exhibit high TOFs [24,25]. However, this reported Ru particle size effect does not apply to the present results since the Ru particle sizes of the Ru/SiO2 and Ru/CLS0 catalysts were determined to be 2–3 and 5.5 nm, respectively, as described above. Furthermore, electron donation from the support to the Ru sites has been reported to be effective in promoting the dissociative adsorption of N2, which represents the rate-limiting step in the ammonia synthesis reaction. Considering that the oxides of Ce3+ are typically effective supports [30], the TOFs of the Ru/CLSX catalysts (i.e., the activity of the Ru sites) depends on whether the Ru sites are affected by the CeOx or SiO2 support. The operando XAFS results demonstrated that in the Ru/CLSX catalysts, the interaction between Ru and CeOx was stronger at lower Si contents. Therefore, we conclude that the reduced TOFs observed for the Ru/CLSX catalysts at higher Si contents were attributed to weaker electron donation from the support to the Ru sites. This could be due to an increase in the percentage of Ru sites on the SiO2 support compared to those on the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution support. Overall, it was found that the Ru/CLS10 catalyst exhibited the highest activity, which may be due to the additional influence of the abundant Ru sites, in addition to the effect of the Ru-site activity (i.e., the TOF). Fig. 11 illustrates the relationship between the characteristics and activities of the Ru/CLSX catalysts. More specifically, the CeO2-La2O3 support of the Ru/CLS0 catalyst exhibits an extremely small SSA and pore volume, resulting in a low Ru dispersion and activity. Si doping produced fine CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution particles, which increased both the SSA and the pore volume (by 10–50 nm), resulting in an improved Ru dispersion. In the case of the Ru/CLS10 catalyst, little agglomeration of SiO2 was observed, and the majority of Ru was highly dispersed on the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 support. These characteristics affect both the quality (activity) and quantity of the Ru sites, thereby accounting for the optimal catalytic activity observed for this species. Further Si doping produced an agglomerated SiO2 support on which some Ru was loaded. As a result, the activities of the Ru/CLSX catalysts where X ≥ 20 decreased with an increasing Si content because the Ru sites on the SiO2 support were less active. 4 Conclusions A series of Ru/CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 catalysts were prepared using a polymerization complexation method, and their catalytic activities were evaluated for the synthesis of ammonia under mild conditions (≤5.1 MPa). It was clearly demonstrated that an optimized level of Si doping enhanced the ammonia synthesis activity of a Ru/CeO2-La2O3 catalyst through the creation of a mesoporous structure. Additionally, characterization by scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffractometry, N2 adsorption, attenuated total reflection–Fourier transform infrared spectrometry, and CO adsorption measurements revealed that Si doping at levels of up to 10 mol% created a mesoporous structure within the 10–50 nm pore size range. This was achieved through aggregation of fine CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution particles, and resulted in an enhanced Ru dispersion along with a superior catalytic activity. However, Si doping at levels above 10 mol% generated isolated SiO2 particles and increased the number of inactive Ru species (i.e., supported on SiO2), resulting in a reduced catalytic activity. Consequently, an optimal range exists for Si doping in the CeO2-La2O3 support, and highly active Ru catalysts can be designed by appropriately controlling the amount of Si incorporated into the structure. Notably, the Ru/CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 catalyst containing 10 mol% Si doping exhibited a 3.5-fold higher rate of ammonia synthesis at 5.1 MPa than the catalyst without Si doping. This study is expected to promote the synthesis of ammonia under mild conditions by efficiently utilizing the Ru active sites, which will ultimately contribute to the transition from a fossil fuel-based society to a hydrogen-based society. coredata.dc:description: Green ammonia has attracted growing attention as an energy carrier to facilitate the storage and transport of hydrogen that is derived from renewable energy sources. It is therefore necessary to develop catalysts that can efficiently synthesize ammonia under milder conditions (<10 MPa) than those required by conventional catalysts (15–30 MPa). In this study, Si is doped into Ru/CeO2-La2O3 catalysts prepared via a polymerization complexation method to promote the synthesis of ammonia over the generated mesoporous structure. Scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffractometry, N2 adsorption, attenuated total reflection–Fourier transform infrared spectrometry, and CO adsorption measurements revealed that for the CeO2-La2O3 support, Si doping at levels of ≤ 10 mol% created a mesoporous structure (10–50 nm range) through aggregation of the CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 solid solution with a smaller particle size than that of undoped particles. Consequently, this resulted in an enhanced Ru dispersion and an improved catalytic activity. However, Si doping at levels > 10 mol% led to the formation of isolated SiO2 particles bearing inactive Ru species, thereby resulting in a lower catalytic activity. Notably, compared to the catalyst without Si doping, the 10 mol% Si-doped Ru/CeO2-La2O3-SiO2 catalyst exhibited a 3.5-fold higher rate for ammonia synthesis at a reaction pressure of 5.1 MPa. This system is therefore expected to promote ammonia synthesis under mild conditions, ultimately contributing to the transition from a fossil fuel-based society to a hydrogen-based society.
